Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: Ramadan’s midpoint arrives and the daily reading quota is slightly behind.
Story: I sat at my desk, the soft hum of the office air conditioning barely masking the ping of a new email. It was from one of our regular vendors—a standard automated confirmation of the payment I’d processed yesterday. Company policy was clear: every confirmation, no matter how routine, deserved a formal reply. I opened a draft, fingers poised over the keyboard, but my mind wandered. Ramadan had reached its midpoint, and I was already behind on my daily Quran reading. The guilt pressed on me; I’d promised myself to catch up today, to not let work crowd out my spiritual commitments. Yet here I was, expected to be the diligent accountant, responsive and professional, while the quiet voice inside reminded me of my duty as a Muslim—to recite, to reflect, to reconnect. The minutes ticked by, each one a tug-of-war between the demands of my job and the longing in my heart to fulfill my faith. I stared at the screen, torn, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which to answer first.
